newsitem.title: MEXICO: Tribasa to announce new partners to bid on railway.
newsitem.headline: Tribasa to announce new partners to bid on railway.

text.p: Grupo Tribasa said Friday it will announce in coming weeks new partners in its consortium to bid in the privatization of Mexico's national railways.

"We are on the verge, perhaps in a couple of weeks, of announcing new partners to try to strengthen our position. We have been in negotiations with prominent groups, both Mexican and U.S.," Fernando Gutierrez, vice president of operations told Reuters.

Tribasa and its partners, RailTex and Impulsora Tlaxcalteca de Industrias (Itisa), announced Friday they will bid on the Pacific-North route, after recently withdrawing from the Chihuahua-Pacific bidding. The Pacific-North line starts in Colima state and runs toward the U.S. border and is due to be awarded next April or May.
In the consortium as it stands, Tribasa has a 50 percent stake, and the other two partners have 25 percent apiece.
"Certainly those stakes will be diluted with the incorporation of new partners," Gutierrez said.
He added that if Tribasa and its parners decide to bid on the Northeast line, they would join one of the other groups already bidding.

The Northeast line is considered the most attractive in Mexico's railway privatization package. It connects Nuevo Laredo, Monterrey and Mexico City, and carried 30-40 percent of Mexico's rail cargo in 1995.
At present, there are seven groups registered to bid of which two have prequalified. Some analysts believe the section may draw bids of over $600 million.
"Certainly more groups will be approved (to bid on the Northeast line). We would join the one that offers the most advantages to all involved," said Gutierrez.
